1.33.text: What are you baking for us today Sixie?

3.16.text:
I’m baking one of Mel’s specialities - carrot
cake with low-fat carrot icing and a glass

7.40.text: of carrot juice, carrot juice, carrot juice...

10.13.text:
Ah! Jelly Baby cake my dear. Would you care
for one? They’re rather good.

14.07.text:
So, we’ve heard their menus, but which baking
Baker boy will bake the best baking?!

18.84.text:
Find out in The Great Intergalactic Baker
Off!!

21.51.text: Christel jumps and hastily hides the dollies.

34.86.text: Hello and welcome to the Fan Show.

39.16.text:
This week we’re in the kitchen and I’m
joined by Great British Bake Off winner and

43.20.text: resident Doctor Who baker, Edd Kimber.

47.31.text: So what are we making today?

48.31.text:
So today we’re making a TARDIS out of Battenberg.
So kind of TARDIS inspired. Nice and blue

53.21.text: and really easy to make as well.

57.54.text:
So we’ve got our ready made cake. All we’ve
got in here is butter and sugar that has been

60.94.text:
And then we added some eggs, some vanilla
and some almond extract. And then we’ve

65.12.text:
added some flour, almonds and a little bit
of baking powder.

67.54.text:
Really, really easy. Really, really simple.
Just a basic cake sponge.

69.87.text:
Then all we’re going to do is divide it
in half and what we’re going to do is add

74.78.text:
So because the TARDIS windows are kind of
two shades, we’re going to add real black

78.45.text:
to one of them and just a little bit to the
other.

81.30.text: So one should be a lot lighter than the other.

83.32.text:
What you want to do is make sure you mix it
thoroughly so you don’t want any streaks

86.17.text:
of white because that will show up in the
actual cake as well.

89.39.text:
All we’re going to do is divide our batter
into our cake tins.

92.07.text:
And all we’ve done is lightly grease them
and line them with a strip of parchment which

96.21.text: makes lifting up the cake a lot easier later.

98.05.text: So you’re going to put yours into that one.

100.25.text: I’ll put mine into this one.

101.80.text: That’s it. Just right into the middle.

103.53.text:
And then we should be able to spread it out
into a nice, even layer. And just tease it

110.15.text:
into the corners so you get nice, straight
sided squares.

112.65.text:
So once they’re in our cake tins we’re
just gonna put those in the oven for 25-30

118.79.text:
And the way you can test they’re done is
if you lightly press them and it just springs

122.55.text:
If you put a little tooth pick or skewer into
the middle it should come out clean.

125.26.text:
And then you’ll leave them in the tins to
cool down for 15 minutes because they need

128.12.text:
to be really cold before we can construct
the cake otherwise it’ll fall into pieces.

132.42.text:
While that’s in the oven, here are some
of our fave Doctor Who bakes from around the

135.98.text:
internet – a veritable feast of Time Lord
tasties.

138.93.text:
Join Sorted Food’s resident Whovian, Ben,
for this awesome Dalek Bread recipe. The special

143.53.text: ingredient is ground up Dalek apparently.

147.54.text:
Thirsty after repeatedly reversing the polarity?
Mitch from Geek & Sundry has created a mocktail

152.51.text:
inspired by the favoured tool of the Doctor,
the Sonic Screwdriver!

156.19.text:
Impress your friends with Cupcake Jemma’s
awesome Dalek cupcakes. Complete with edible

162.29.text:
And finally, if you’re looking for a ghoulish
treat to make this Wholloween, why not rustle

167.14.text:
A very disgusting but delicious bake, from
- well, you Edd.

171.73.text: How long have we got left?

176.48.text:
Any way we speed things up? It is a time travel
show after all...

188.59.text: So what are we doing here?

190.45.text:
So what we’re doing is we’re just going
to trim off the edges so we’ve got a nice

194.38.text:
Square so when we cut and construct the cake
it’s got nice, even edges.

198.08.text:
And I guess that’s why we smooth down the
top as well?

200.23.text:
Yeah, so we can try and get a nice flat surface
when it bakes.

204.17.text: How do we assemble the Battenberg?

205.33.text:
What we need to do is take our marzipan. So
this is white marzipan because it will take

210.57.text:
So don’t use the yellow stuff because you’ll
end up with a green colour.

212.62.text:
So all we’re gonna do is kind of fold it
in half and make like a little indent there.

217.72.text: And we’re gonna take our colours.

218.72.text:
To make our TARDIS blue we’re gonna use
a mix of navy and royal blue.

222.95.text:
Encase this into the marzipan first so it
doesn’t initially get onto your hands then

230.24.text: all we do is knead it through.

234.08.text: So that eventually we get a nice, blue marzipan.

238.24.text:
And now we’ve got to clean because this
is not contusive to baking!

242.13.text:
So all we need to do now is cut our cake into
equal size pieces. Four of the black and two

247.59.text:
There will be a little bit of cake left over.
And the cake needs to be nice and cool for

250.24.text:
this because if it’s warm it will crumble
and fall apart.

253.52.text:
I don’t have a sonic screwdriver, I have
a dusting wand.

258.93.text:
I’m just going to cover the surface with
a little bit of icing sugar. And this just

263.78.text: means that the marzipan doesn’t stick.

266.28.text:
But you don’t use flour because when you
eat it, it will just taste gummy.

268.89.text:
So we’re just going to use a little bit
of icing sugar.

271.76.text:
So just onto there, press it down so you can
start it already.

275.14.text: Dust that with a little bit of icing sugar.

277.07.text:
And then what we need to do is roll it out
so that it’s long enough and wide enough

283.18.text:
so we can roll the whole thing onto it’s
side.

286.44.text: That is problaby about long enough.

288.51.text:
So all we’ve done is we’ve turned it over
so most of the icing sugar is on the inside

291.75.text: so we get that nice blue outside.

292.85.text:
Then we’re going to take some butter cream
and spread it all over.

297.19.text: And how have you made the butter cream?

298.58.text: This is a really classic butter cream.

299.66.text:
Just 100g of butter and 200g or sugar. A little
bit of vanilla and a little bit of lemon oil

303.83.text: just to give it a bit of flavor as well.

307.94.text:
This is only meant to be a thin layer and
this is basically edible glue.

311.42.text:
So all we need to do now is construct it.
It’s really, really simple.

313.81.text:
You just have to replicate the look of the
window.

316.09.text:
We’re just going to place one of our grey
windows right on the end.

321.73.text:
And then to make that stick again, we’re
just going to cover this side with a little

328.78.text: bit of butter cream as well.

330.87.text:
It’s just enough to seal in the cake so
that it sticks and doesn’t fall apart when

337.95.text:
And then we’re going to take the next one
which is our black and just place that in.

340.72.text:
And you want to give it a nice squeeze so
that it sticks.

344.90.text:
Because traditionally you’d use jam and
jam is a lot sticker than butter cream so

347.48.text: you just need to give it a little help.

349.46.text:
And then exactly the same again. Just a little
bit of butter cream.

353.77.text:
Don’t worry about crumbs because this will
crumb quite a lot but once you assemble it

357.61.text: you won’t know so it’s fine.

358.95.text:
What you want to do is take our knife and
trim off the outside edge here. Just so we’ve

366.15.text: got a nice clean edge to start with.

368.79.text:
And then I tip very carefully. Try and keep
this roll nice and tight otherwise you end

374.73.text: up with kind of loose on the side.

376.95.text:
And then carefully again. And then once last
time like that.

386.36.text:
Trim off the ends to make a neater finish.
Just very gently cut through. Just nice gentle

393.35.text:
And don’t worry that you’re going to loose
the shape on this because you will the first

399.25.text: We need to lift it onto something to serve.

400.25.text:
We’re just going to use a pallet knife just
to tease underneath so that we can lift it

404.81.text: off nice and easily and place onto our tray.

409.01.text:
And then if you’ve got somewhere where you’ve
cut, gently just press it back. Get rid of

415.28.text:
And we’re going to decorate the top to make
it look like the panel on the front of the

420.98.text:
All we’re gonna do is take some white sugar
paste, some white fondant. And roll it out

424.04.text: on a lightly dusted surface with icing sugar.

426.46.text:
And then roll it out to again, half a centimeter
thick.

430.28.text:
And then we’re going to cut a square that’s
just smaller than the top of our TARDIS.

434.32.text: And then place that onto the top of the cake.

436.56.text:
We’re just going to brush the back of it
with a little bit of water which will act

440.73.text:
And then once it’s on there we’re just
going to use an edible marker pen to very

443.82.text: carefully write on the police box details.

448.04.text:
Well thank you so much Edd for baking this
for us and if you want to have a go, full

450.72.text:
details of the recipe are available in the
description below.

452.83.text:
Let’s have a look at some of the Doctor
Who bakes you’ve sent in.

455.96.text:
Samantha H sent us a picture of a Police Box
cake and check out these Jammie Dodgers!

460.00.text:
James S and his girlfriend decorated these
Dalek cupcakes – cunningly using a jelly

465.94.text:
And Daniel F got this delicious Dalek birthday
cake. As Missy would say, yummy!

470.69.text:
And if you have a go at making your own TARDIS
Battenberg cake send us pics at dwthefanshow@bbc.com

477.88.text: I guess we should try some!

479.31.text: I’d love to but I’m wheat intolerant!

484.85.text: I’ll have some! I’ll take it!
